At-a-Glance: Well-sited swarm traps catch primary swarms ethically and safely. Feral colony removals require planning, permits, and public safety considerations.
Why it Matters: Trapped swarms provide local genetics and relieve neighbourhood concerns.
Unsafe removals damage property and reputation.
Clear protocols protect bees, people, and legal standing.
Objectives: Deploy traps before peak season in optimal locations.
Use humane, legal methods to collect and rehome swarms.
Assess feral removals realistically with risk and permissions.
What Good Looks Like: 40 litre box volume, small entrance, old comb lure, lemon grass oil sparingly.
Traps mounted 3–5 m high with safe access and labelled contact details.
Removals done with written permission, containment plan, and insurance.
Step-by-Step: 1) Trap build: weatherproof box, small south or east entrance, secure hanger.
2) Bait: one old dark comb plus a drop or two of lemon grass oil on a cotton swab.
3) Placement: near previous swarm flight paths, tree lines, and edges; avoid public paths.
4) Checks: inspect weekly; once occupied, wait until evening to move.
5) Transfer: install into a prepared hive with frames; feed lightly if dearth.
6) Feral removals: scope access, structure type, and colony size; plan bee vac and cutout with dust control; agree property repair responsibilities in writing.
Seasonality & Climate: Deploy traps 2–4 weeks before local swarm season.
In cool springs, extend deployment as flights may delay.
Data & Thresholds: Box volume near 40 litres wins more catches in many regions.
One old comb is enough; too many attract pests.
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Symptom: Repeated scout visits but no occupancy -> Adjust height or entrance orientation; try nearby alternative site.
Symptom: Ant invasion -> Relocate trap and refresh lure; use grease on hanger if safe.
Symptom: Feral removal beyond safe scope -> Refer to specialist with access gear and insurance.
Common Pitfalls: Over-scenting with oils that repel rather than attract.
Mounting traps where retrieval is unsafe.
Taking on structural cutouts without permission or repair plan.
Tools & Techniques: Swarm boxes, straps, ladders with stabilisers, bee vac with gentle suction.
Sheeting, tape, debris control, spare nucs and frames.
Safety & Compliance: Use fall protection where required; avoid power lines.
Written permissions and insurance for property work.
Follow local wildlife and pest control regulations.
Field Checklist: Removals have written consent and risk assessment.
Communications: Provide a neighbour leaflet on what to do if they see a swarm.
Further Reading: Research on preferred swarm cavity volume and entrance size.
Best practice guides for safe removals and public liaison.
Notes: Keep a simple catch log with GPS, date, weather, and subsequent queen status.
